comments.text:
+wuuspigs
You're confused on so many different level, it's hard to know where to 
start.

Why don't you start by telling us what the mistake was in the Breivik's 
story? And do you expect people to always get things right? Are you never 
wrong about anything? There's a difference between being wrong on one 
Breivik's story and being wrong most of times on a wide variety of 
subjects. There is also a difference between an honest mistake leading to a 
flawed anaysis and deliberately spreading wrong information in order to 
further an agenda. And there's also a difference between doing that once 
and doing it systematically.

Also people don't just form opinions by looking at the facts. Most people 
have already made up their mind before the facts are even presented to 
them. Others are influenced by other people's opinion, and that's not being 
weak minded, it's insightful to hear people's points of view and 
perspectives on the world and to use their analysis to shape own's view of 
the world.

Finally, you naively seem to think that there is such think as "the facts". 
There is no such thing. What you have is perception of the facts. By 
definition, no one can see facts from an objective viewpoint, it's 
impossible, you see them through your own eyes, your own educational bias, 
your own environment, your own political leanings. When something complex 
happens, different people will see different things. That's why objectively 
speaking, in a complex world, there is no such thing as the facts, only 
opinion about what the facts are.

Comcast needs government approval to merge with Time-Warner because of 
something called the Sherman Anti-Trust Act which was enacted in 1890. 
Since then corporations have done everything in their power to render it a 
nullity. The fact that corporations now own the government means that of 
the thousand or so anti-trust actions that *should* have been taken by the 
government over the last 20 years, only two or three were actually taken. 
That's why we have "too big to fail" financial institutions, an oligopoly 
in mass media, and the US as a society falling backwards on virtually every 
quality of life index.


Piers Morgan, incidentally, is a brain-dead repeater of the dominant 
ideology - and so of course it would never occur to him to say anything 
that challenges it. That's why he is where he is.﻿

comments.text:
No, pure socialism doesn't work and just creates more problems, as does 
pure libertarianism. The social democratic system is a decent compromise 
and works best for now. In the long-term, we will need to develop an 
entirely new economic system - one in which all manual labor from 
agriculture to manufacturing to services is entirely automated, so the 
quaternary sector can flourish. Space colonization will also be necessary 
to provide infinite land and resources, thus eradicating poverty and most 
conflict. Trans-humanism can also empower mankind further by drastically 
increasing longevity and living standards.

In this world we won't need money - everything will simply be made for us. 
We will focus on doing what we enjoy rather than what we're forced to do to 
pay the bills - we can study, do scientific research, invent new machines 
and achieve other feats of engineering, write books, music and poetry, 
create films and games, focus on politics, teaching, history, law, media, 
medicine or just raising a family, recreating and exploring nature in a 
care-free world. Obviously this world is still far off, by we're in the 
early stages as we've seen from industry becoming increasingly automated, 
space colonization being more frequently talked about and technology being 
increasingly integrated with our bodies. Once the groundwork is laid there 
will be exponential growth.

Currently a significant proportion of the populations of developed 
countries study at university, while jobs in manufacturing are lost to 
machines. A new economic system is needed to address this, and it seems the 
quaternary sector is all we'll have left to do in an automated world. We 
will work with our brains rather than our hands. But this is a good thing - 
finally work will be about what we enjoy rather than what we're forced to 
do by our circumstances, and we'll be unleashing our true potential. The 
brain is what makes a human such a special creature and it's an incredibly 
powerful organ. That is what we should be dedicating our time and energy to 
- not menial tasks that machines can do for us.

comments.text:
+BlunderCity You vastly underestimate the level of corruption in the US 
(where rampant cronyism and corruption in the finance/banking sector almost 
directly took down the entire global economy).  The US Dept. of Justice 
investigates its own crimes... enough said.  Just ask James Trafficant how 
quickly they can get rid of anyone who doesn't "tow the Republicrat line".

You also underestimate the extent to which living standards have improved 
under Putin.  He has the Russian birth-rate now moving in a positive 
direction (they are around normal replacement levels of fertility whereas 
Russians were systematically dying off like the Japanese are today), he 
modernized the Russian military, and implemented economic reforms that 
worked very well.  And it did not take very long for these noticeable 
improvements to transpire.

*He had some luck (like Ergodan, as you mention)... but he also played his 
cards right.  It's hard to deny that the man is a strong, natural leader.  
And if Russians prefer nostalgic celebrations of their shared culture and a 
more autocratic version of "democracy", so what??  That is THEIR 
prerogative. Who on Earth has the right to dictate to the Russian people 
what leaders they can or cannot approve of??*

Regarding Russia ALWAYS being powerful... that is untrue.  Sure they always 
had nuclear warheads since the late 1940's... but the army as in a decrepit 
state during the late 80's through the 90's and into the new millennium 
before Putin made a concerted effort at modernization.

Do you really think Yeltsin's Russia had the power or geopolitical clout to 
almost single-handedly prevent and block the planned deployment of US 
soldiers to fight alongside Al-Qaida/Al-Nusra, as Washington again tried to 
play king-maker getting involved in the Syrian Civil War??

Yeltsin was a drunken lackey.  He licked Clinton's boots and did whatever 
the US told him to... part of the reason Russia was in such a sorry state 
of affairs in the 1990's.  Yeltsin was a weak leader who let the Oligarchs 
rule the broken nation with virtual impunity... the Oligarchs had more 
power than Yeltsin himself during Boris' second term.

There is no way in hell the US takes a Russian veto on the UN security 
council seriously under Yeltsin's Russia. America would simply ignore UN 
objections and do whatever they feel like; just as they did in Serbia. 
Putin's Russia is a Russia that emphatically rejects the prior shame of 
being the world's largest doormat.

*Of course, the US would prefer Russia be ruled by a Boris Yeltsin type.  
Putin's biggest crime was providing the geopolitical counter-balance that 
ceased to exist with the fall of the Soviet Union.  Putin is the main world 
figure forcing US foreign policy-makers to keep things honest (at least to 
some degree).*

It's worth repeating, the level of corruption in the EU/UK/US is far higher 
than you think.  The 1% control almost everything... and any improvements 
in the economy (they are few and far between) mostly benefit that 1%.

*Oh, and in Russia there is not a multi-billiion dollar gravy train of 
endless war profits -- dependent on an extremely lucrative war machine 
(military-industrial complex) -- and a constant state of aggression and 
occupation.*

*Russia is not exporting violence and war, and is not profiting from such 
an unethical foreign policy, the way the US has been for the past decade.  
When Putin starts acting like somebody gave him a "World Police Badge"... i 
will criticize him for it.*

But as of now... Putin is not involving Russia in conflicts thousands and 
thousands of miles away from the nation's borders.  The same cannot be said 
for some Western powers; who are forcefully trying to shape the world as 
they see fit.

I'll leave it at that.  Putin is no saint, and he definitely has autocratic 
tendencies, but since Russians haven't forgotten how terrible their 
national leadership was before Putin -- and how much worse off the entire 
population was before the Putin era -- they still generally regard him 
highly, or at least tolerate him.

If Russians do not want US-style "democracy", why should anybody force it 
on them??  It is up to Russians to decide their own fate, not the leaders 
of any foreign nation.
comments.author: bobshenix

comments.text:
+bobshenix
I think you misunderstood what I was saying.

Yes I am aware of the chaos that prevailed in the 90s in Russia, which was 
nothing special, totally standard stuff after a revolution (and tamed by 
historical standards, certainly nothing compared to the civil war)

Yes he did inherit a mess (all the stuff you mentioned to which I would add 
the aftermath of a financial crisis and separatist conflicts in the south). 
But I would much rather to be put in charge of Russia in 2000 than in 1992!

No it wasn't all Yeltsin's fault, most of what happened would probably have 
played out with another guy at the helm.

But I think you're way too focused on the fine print. When you inherit the 
largest country on Earth, the richest in natural resources, a decent sized 
population, a seat at the UN Security council, the second most powerful 
armed forces in the world, hundreds of years of proud history and culture, 
you're never going to be Albania!

You said Putin made Russia great. Russia was always great and probably 
always will be by the very nature of what it is. It is not difficult to 
make a country one of the most powerful in the world when it is Russia. But 
with the rising trend of emerging economies and $100/barrel oil, Russia 
ought to be doing a lot better. And Putin arrived just at the time when 
large emerging economies were taking off (the 2000s). The same can be 
applied to Erdogan in Turkey, he's not solely responsible for the relative 
good health of the Turkish economy. The last decade almost completely 
belonged to economies of that type, namely BRICs and MINTs (China, Brazil, 
India, Russia, Mexico, Indonesia, Turkey).

Corruption exists in every country? Are you seriously saying the level of 
corruption in Russia is similar to that of the US or western Europe? If 
that's the case, you should get your head examined.

Comparing approval ratings across the world is a ridiculous exercise 
because the political culture and reality is different from one country to 
the next. And attitudes towards government couldn't be different in Russia 
and in the US: Russians love strong autocratic leaders, they bring order 
and flatter the populace with romantic nationalism. In the US, approval 
ratings are generally determined by the state of the economy. I heard that 
popularity ratings comparison nonesense in a debate just yesterday: This 
moron claimed that Yanukovitch had approval ratings that were nearly double 
that of Francois Hollande, President of France (19%). Yeah that's because 
Yanukovitch was a very polarising figure who had a large core of die hard 
supporters while half of his country hated him to the point that they were 
willing to die to get rid of him. Not the case in France, he's nicknamed 
"le flan" (a soft custard dessert that wobbles), he's the biggest 
irrelevance in the history of politics! Hollande's popularity is low cos 
the French, my fellow countrymen by the way, are a bunch of cry babies who 
really ought to grow up!
comments.author: BlunderCity

comments.text:
+BlunderCity Is that a joke??  Putin inherited a lawless mafia state with 
Boris "drunk at the wheel" Yeltsin letting transnational oligarchs funnel 
the natural wealth out of Russia.  Ask any Russian... the 1990's were an 
absolute nightmare.

The entire reason the oligarchs groomed Putin as their next doormat (big 
mistake, as Putin was just biding his time to rid Russia of these 
scoundrels) is because he won over their trust, and he projected a strong 
image.  Especially compared to Yeltsin, who was completely blacked out for 
most of his second term.  Putin was young, active, has a black-belt in 
judo, etc. etc.

Putin was the face they needed because things had gotten so bad in Russia 
that the Communist Part was actually beginning to make headway in the late 
90's.  Even after former Soviet states repudiated Communism just several 
years prior. They helped Putin become a household name... but Putin later 
turned on them because he was aware that his country was being raped of its 
natural wealth.

Keep in mind, the "kingmaker" oligarchs i speak of bought entire 
former-Soviet industries for *pennies on the dollar* and made enormous 
fortunes.  The price they paid was far, far less than the actual worth of 
the Russian industries that were privatized in the early 90's.

*Putin inherited an absolute MESS!!!*. Russians have not forgotten the 
misery of the Yeltsin years, and so they cut Putin some slack with some of 
his autocratic tendencies... they'll take that.  Russian living standards 
are much, much higher than they ever were during the Communist Stagnancy 
and the chaotic Yeltsin "shock treatment" years.

OF COURSE there is corruption in Russia.  *There is corruption in every 
nation on Earth;* but Putin brought the level of corruption from 
out-of-control to just regular corruption.

And that is, in part, the reason why he enjoys relatively high approval 
ratings... higher than Obama or Bush enjoyed in the US.  Putin is more 
popular internationally too, because he is not seen as the root cause of 
all the wars that the US "World Police Task Force" has undertaken.
